  For each node: 
   
   pass a client timestamp in the snapshot call corresponding to "now" 
   snapshot the tables using the existing procedure 
   walk backwards through the linked snapshot sstables in that snapshot 
   if the earliest update in that sstable is after the client's timestamp, delete the sstable in the snapshot 
   if the earliest update in the sstable is before the client's timestamp, then look at the last update.

text: Catalog loading threads can be wasted waiting for a large table to load.
label: yes

text: When there are multiple requests to the catalogd to prioritize loading the same table, then several catalog loading threads may end up waiting for that single table to be loaded, effectively reducing the number of catalog loading threads.
label: yes

text: After issuing a load request, an impalad will wait 2m for the metadata to arrive, and then send the request again every 2m.
label: yes

text: So if a large table takes 20m to load, then a single query could issue 10 table-loading requests which ultimately hog 10 table-loading threads in the catalogd.
label: yes

text: However, the code does not prevent multiple threads from entering Catalog.getTableOrLoad() which will block on the same future for the same table.

text: rethink stress test binary search cutoff point.

text:
While working on 
   <URL> I see that during a binary search, a lot of queries that are meant to be tested with spilling are not set at any different mem_limit than they were for their non-spillable counterparts.
label: yes

text: This is due to both the default data scales of the stress test (TPCH 100, TPCDS 300) and the fact that <tt>MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB = 50 in <tt>concurrent_select.py.
label: yes

text: For queries that only use roughly 200 MB, a 50MB threshold is a rather large percentage.
label: yes

text: This means the binary search is "giving up" sooner than it could.
label: yes

text:
There are some options: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   drop MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB completely and only rely on MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_PC, which is 0.975.
label: yes

text: For a 200 MB query, this would effectively be a threshold of 5MB.
label: yes

text: This would lead to a more precise binary search, but one that would take longer to complete.
label: yes

text: keep MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB but only put it in play for either larger queries or larger data sets.
label: yes

text: If the column ranges are large (i.e. multiple I/O buffers) or we're reading from SSDs where random access is fairly efficient, this may not matter very much.
label: yes

text: If we are reading each column into a single smaller I/O buffer but multiple columns would fit in a larger I/O buffer, we would probably be better off doing a single I/O for that column.
label: yes

text: Sorting the scan ranges by file offset would improve the odds of being able to read each subsequent column without an additional seek and will also improve locality for the disk's internal cache.
label: yes

text: Based on some superficial googling, a lot of drives have 64M or 128M internal caches, which is large enough that it could be useful but small enough that, if we do I/O from a 256MB+ Parquet file in a completely random order, we're reducing the chances of getting cache hits significantly.
label: yes

text: may help a lot here, since it will tell us upfront what the memory budget is for I/O.

text: While debugging performance issues in a Spark program, I've found a simple way to slow down Spark 1.6 significantly by filling the RDD memory cache.
label: yes

text: This seems to be a regression, because setting "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" fixes the problem.
label: yes

text:
Here is a repro that is just a simple program that fills the memory cache of Spark using a MEMORY_ONLY cached RDD (but of course this comes up in more complex situations, too): 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  If I call it the following way, it completes in around 5 minutes on my Laptop, while often stopping for slow Full GC cycles.
label: yes

text: I can also see with jvisualvm (Visual GC plugin) that the old generation of JVM is 96.8% filled.
label: yes

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  If I add any one of the below flags, then the run-time drops to around 40-50 seconds and the difference is coming from the drop in GC times: --conf "spark.memory.fraction=0.6" OR --conf "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" OR --driver-java-options "-XX:NewRatio=3" 
  All the other cache types except for DISK_ONLY produce similar symptoms.
label: yes

text: It looks like that the problem is that the amount of data Spark wants to store long-term ends up being larger than the old generation size in the JVM and this triggers Full GC repeatedly.
label: yes

text:
I did some research: 
   
   In Spark 1.6, spark.memory.fraction is the upper limit on cache size.
label: yes

text: In Spark 1.5, spark.storage.memoryFraction is the upper limit in cache size.
label: yes

text:
It defaults to 0.6 and... 
   
    <URL> even says that it shouldn't be bigger than the size of the old generation.
label: yes

text: On the other hand, OpenJDK's default NewRatio is 2, which means an old generation size of 66%.
label: yes

text:
This is not a surprise: 
   <URL> explains that storageFraction is not an upper-limit but a lower limit-like thing on the size of Spark's cache.
label: yes

text: The real upper limit is spark.memory.fraction.
label: yes

text: Is it a goal for Spark to support heavy caching with default parameters and without GC breakdown?
label: yes

text:
For instance:

Start with a new repository and create the following hierarchy:

a -- b -- d
  |
  +- c


Create a dump filtered to include only the a/b hierarchy:

$ svnadmin dump repos | svndumpfilter include a/b >dump.txt"


Import the filtered dump into a newly created repository:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ...svn: File not found: transaction '1', path 'a/b'
$


A workaround should be to create the a directory before importing:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ... done.

text: Rather than just blocking when RAM is full we could have a high-water mark where we start spooling messages to disk if there is not sufficient RAM to hold the messages.
label: yes

text: The good thing about this approch is that it avoids blocking the producers when RAM is full; the downside is that once spooling starts, the producer will be slowed down to the speed of the disk spooling (as due to RAM exhaustion under steady state, the producer will have to wait for the message to be spooled to disk so that it can evict it from RAM so that it can send the next message).
label: yes

text: Though the journal is quite fast so the slow down shouldn't be too many orders of magnitude (and is better than making things appear to 'lock up' while we wait for the slowest consumer to acknowledge more messages).
label: yes

text: We typically use the current thread in the broker to dispatch to all the available non-durable consumers for performance - as this hugely reduces the context switching and increases performance.
label: yes

text:
However (see 
   <URL>) sometimes this can cause one dead consumer to block a producer.
label: yes

text: Some folks may want to switch this strategy to use slower asynchronous dispatch with a thread pool to reduce the risk of blocking a producer at the expensive of lower performance
label: yes

label: yes

text: Now with the new code, when I return to the game after minutes of being idle I see the game where I left it but for like 3 seconds only and then the game restarts.
label: yes

text: Propagate queue subscription selectors to virtual topic dispatch such that unmatched messages do not pile up on subscription queues.
label: no

text: With virtual topics each consumer can get its own queue or share an existing queue.
label: no

text:
<URL> 
  Consumers which share a queue, can use selectors to partition the consumer queue but individual consumers that use selectors run into a problem in that the dispatch to the queue does not take account of the selector and all messages are dispatched to the queue.
label: no

text: Over time, the unmatched messages build up on the queue.
label: no

text: Through static configuration it is possible to arrange that the destination queues are filtered, but this solution is static.
label: no

text: An alternative approach, that does impose a cpu hit during dispatch (as the selectors are executed twice) can provide a neat solution.
label: no

text: Making a virtual topic selectorAware allows the destination interceptor to only dispatch messages that match the selector of one of the existing subscriptions.
label: no

text: In this way, no unmatched messages will be dispatched to the subscription queues.
label: no

text:
In xml configuration, the following will make all topic dispatch respect the selectors of the existing subscriptions: 
  <SOURCECODE>

text: Currently shared storage master/slave locking is a job of a persistence adapter.

text: JDBCPersistenceAdapter can ignore statements settings depending on configuration order.
label: no

text: When a jdbcPersistenceAdapter is configured using the "adapter" attribute (as below), the tablePrefix specified in the statements element is ignored during table creation.
label: no

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  It seems spring is calling the org.apache.activemq.store.jdbc.JDBCPersistenceAdapter.setAdapter() method before org.apache.activemq.store.jdbc.JDBCPersistenceAdapter.setStatements() is called.
label: no

text: The setAdapter() triggers the table creation - hence no *tablePrefix" is used.
label: no

text: This problems can be worked around if the adapter is configured as an element (as below) however this isn't the most ideal fix.
label: no

text: JDBCPersistence DB stopped during message send; JMSException is sent back to client rather than shutting down connection.
label: no

text: Broker is configured to use JDBCIOExceptionHandler.
label: no

text: When the JDBCPersistence DB is stopped during a message send the broker returns the following javax.jms.JMSException back to the client rather than closing the connection.
label: no

text: This results in the client having to deal with the exception instead of the failover transport having to deal with a connection loss and redeliver the message.
label: no

text: Failover transport and transport connection loss seems to be the approach used when other SQL exceptions are thrown.

label: no

label: no

label: no

label: no

text: /bin/activemq start as root fails if $ACTIVEMQ_USER is set to user with /bin/csh as login shell.
label: no

text:
Provided the following circumstances: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   Linux/Unix, 
   in the bin/activemq script is used the $ACTIVE_USER variable set to a valid system user which has /bin/csh as default login shell (/etc/passwd) instead of bash, 
   bin/activemq or its symlink to /etc/init.
label: no

text: d is called as root user.
label: no

text:
For the above conditions, ActiveMQ start fails with: 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  Users with /bin/csh as default shell are sometimes required, for instance for using as SAP Netweaver user.
label: no

text: The solution is quite simple: In bin/activemq, find the (two) calls of <tt>su -c ... and replace them by <tt>su -s /bin/sh -c ...' to force bash to be the default shell in each case.
label: no

text: media.stop() should call error callback when called in MEDIA_STARTING state.
label: no

text: On iOS, when calling media.stop() when media is in state MEDIA_STARTING (for example, the player is caching media file), we don't get any callback.
label: no

text: And then, when the caching is completed, the media actually starts playing.
label: no

text:
The proposed fix is that when media.stop() is called in an invalid state, the plugin should send an error callback with the code MEDIA_ERR_NONE_ACTIVE 
  Another approach would be to stop the playback as soon as the player finishes caching.
label: no

text:
One possible advantage of this over the proposed fix would be that MEDIA_ERR_NONE_ACTIVE is not in w3c spec: 
   <URL>

text: Cordova-Plugin-Geolocation requires feature android.hardware.location.gps (android 21+).
label: no

text:
Hello Google Play Developer, 
  We're writing to let you know that the apps listed at the end of this email may be affected by an upcoming platform change.
label: no

text: Action required: If your app requires GPS hardware to operate properly, you will need to explicitly add the "android.hardware.location.gps" uses-feature to your manifest.
label: no

text:
What??? changing 
  We???e making a change on October 15th, 2016 that will affect apps targeting API version 21 (Android 5.0, Lollipop) or higher that use ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION but don't explicitly have the "android.hardware.location.gps" uses-feature.
label: no

text: Going forward, these apps will be available to install on devices that don't have GPS hardware.
label: no

text: In most cases this won't be an issue since Wi-Fi and Cell-ID based location provides high enough fidelity for the typical operation of these apps.
label: no

text: However, any apps that require GPS hardware, such as GPS navigators, should explicitly add the "android.hardware.location.gps" uses-feature to their manifest.
label: no

text: If your app requires GPS to function properly and you do not include android.hardware.location.gps in your manifest declaration, your users may have a poor app experience.
label: no

text: Also, if you???e using the fused location provider and wish to receive the most accurate location samples from GPS (i.e. with PRIORITY_HIGH_ACCURACY), you must include the "android.hardware.location.gps" feature in your app??? manifest to ensure that Google Play only distributes your app to devices with GPS sensors.
label: no

text: You can read more about this change in the Android Developers Help Center.
label: no

text:
Regards, 
  The Google Play Team
label: no

text: Escape backslashes when creating a PBXShellScriptBuildPhase.

label: no

text: When using `pbxProject.addBuildPhase()` to add a new "Run Script" phase, backslashes in the passed script are not properly escaped.
label: no

text: Unescaped backslashes can break the expected behavior of the shell script and result in a malformed *.
label: no

text: pbxproj file.
label: no

text:
The solution should be as simple as modifying the `pbxShellScriptBuildPhaseObj()` function to replace unescaped backslashes with escaped ones in the same way that double quote characters are handled: 
  ```javascript function pbxShellScriptBuildPhaseObj(obj, options, phaseName) { obj.name = '"' + phaseName + '"'; obj.inputPaths = options.inputPaths || []; obj.outputPaths = options.outputPaths || []; obj.shellPath = options.shellPath; obj.shellScript = '"' + options.shellScript.replace(/"/g, '\\"').
label: no

text:
replace(/<br class="atl-forced-newline">/g, '\\\\') + '"'; 
   return obj; } ```

text: PhoneGap iOS 6 -  network.connection.type issue when turning OFF airplane mode.
label: no

text:
30Oct, 2012 
  Apple Bug Report: Problem ID: 12602276  
  -------------------------------------------------------- update on 26Oct, 2012 
  After more investigation I think this probably is an iOS6 issue The PhoneGap API returns "wifi" when the wifi symbol actually shows up ( the radio status probably doesn't matter ) on banner My application will invoke an RPC , which will fail due to error "A server with specified hostname could not be found" Code= 1003 
  So I think the problem is iOS6 lies about the status, It says wifi is ready while it is not entirely.
label: no

text: From my observation error occurs within 15s after wifi symbol shows up.
label: no

text: After 15s almost for sure there will be no network error.
label: no

text: This issue cannot be reproduced on iOS5.
label: no

text:
It could be a problem within a LAN environment too ( I am hitting a server within company domain ) 
  PhoneGap probably got tricked by the iOS network status too.
label: no

text: Maybe there is something else PhoneGap can check, but not sure.
label: no

text: Meanwhile I will lower the bug priority and report an issue to Apple.
label: no

text:
Before making an RPC I use the PG API to check for connectivity: 
   <URL> code snippet: 
   var networkState = navigator.network.connection.type 
   if (networkState == "none" || networkState == "unknown") { //DO NOT make connection } 
  Scenario: ( i am testing on two iPhone4 , one running OS5 ,and one on OS6)  
  1.
label: no

text: Turn ON airplane mode from setting.
label: no

text:
wait until the radio and wifi are fully OFF  
  2.
label: no

text: Expect to see networkState as "unknown" (iOS5 behavior).
label: no

text:
but it returns "wifi" (iOS6) 
  another minor observation - on iOS6 it takes double time to turn off the airplane mode.

text: [iOS] FileTransfer.didReceiveResponse may not return NSHTTPURLResponse.
label: no

text:
When FileTransfer.download() is downloading a file from 
   <URL>, NSURLConnection did not return with NSHTTPURLResponse.
label: no

text: This will fail for apps that copy files from www/, e.g. apps that initialize its database from a pre-built cache packaged in IPA.
label: no

text:
In 
   <URL> (fixed in 2.2.0), the fix assumes all response must be NSHTTPURLResponse.
label: no

text:
So when FileTransfer.download() is downloading from a 
   <URL> URL (e.g. copying file from www/ folder to Documents/), FileTransfer assumed the download operation failed and returned 403.
label: no

text:
Tested if we comment out 
   <URL>, downloading from 
   <URL> works again.
label: no

text:
We need to find out a better fix instead of commenting out 
   <URL>.
label: no

text:
According to 
   <URL>, URL of 
   <URL> is supported.
label: no

text: You can test FileTransfer.download() by calling it with "encodeURI(document.location.href)" as the "source" parameter.

text: CLI builds version number inconsitently between iOS and Android.
label: no

text: I'm hoping this issue isn't just my ignorance, but I'm finding the app version number generation via the CLI to be inconsistent and odd.
label: no

text: iOS and Android both support a version number (which is what is displayed in the app stores), as well as another string, which most people use as a build number.
label: no

text:
E.g. for iOS: 
  Myapp-Info.
label: no

text:
plist: 
  Bundle versions string, short: 1.0.0 (this is what will show in the app store) Bundle version: 0.0.3 (this is some other build number) 
  Android: 
  AndroidManifest.xml: 
  android:versionCode="1" android:versionName="0.0.3" 
  versionName is what shows in the stores, and versionCode is typically used like a build number (as far as I can tell).
label: no

text: My point is, in the cordova.xml, I only have the ability to set one of these version numbers.
label: no

text: There is only a single "version" attribute.
label: no

text: But we need two attributes, so we can set both version strings via the CLI.
label: no

text: Secondly, how the "version" attribute is applied when building via the CLI is inconsistent.
label: no

text: On iOS it's updating the "build" number, and not even touching the main version number that users will see in the store.
label: no

text: Whereas Android has what I would expect as the correct behaviour.
label: no

text: Anyway, please let me know if I've misunderstood anything.
label: no

text: Malfunction OnlineEventsBridgeMode.
label: no

text: While hunting a bug resulting in file API not reporting success/failure during asynchronous calls, we had learned that OnlineEventsBridgeMode (NativeToJsMessageQueue.java) seem to be broken.
label: no

text:
We noticed that from a certain point in time, the Boolean online was always set to false during: toggleNetworkRunnable  { ... webView.setNetworkAvailable(online) } 
    Consequently there were no more online/offline events triggered at the JS and no more consequent polling of messages.
label: no

text: To be more precise, events from JAVA to JS were delivered only when someone from the JS was calling androidExec (cordova.js) and never during online/offline events.
label: no

text: As a result, we were always missing the last set of events as there were stuck down at the JAVA queue resulting in application freeze.
label: no

text: (Once that started, the Boolean online was no longer being toggled via notifyOfFlush resulting in a permanent failure resolved only when reloading the software).
label: no

text: As far as we understand, WebView only deliverers online/offline events to JS if the state of the Network changes i.e. if after a call to webView.setNetworkAvailable(false) one would call webView.setNetworkAvailable(true) and vice versa.
label: no

text: This means that by design, Cordova seeks to maintain the Boolean online to maintain the inverse state of the WebView Network state.
label: no

text: If/when the Boolean online looses track of the WebView Network state, the system online/offline events are discontinued until software reloading.
label: no

text: Till now we were unable to track down the exact sequence leading the Boolean online to loose track of the WebView Network state in our system, but we do notice a sequence of two consecutive calls to notifyOfFlush, flipping the Boolean online twice - thereafter the Boolean online seem to have lost track of the WebView Network state and online/offline events no longer propagated to JS.
label: no

text: If our understanding is indeed correct.....
label: no

text: than, our main concern is that this design does not converge to a stable state and that inview of the asynchronous nature of the design and reliance on WebView specifics, a KISS methodology which would not put the code at risk of coming into a complete halt in view of a single mishap may be better.
label: no

text: I.e. a design with a better self healing property following mishaps.
label: no

text:
We tried out a simple modification by replacing: webView.setNetworkAvailable(online);  with:  webView.setNetworkAvailable(true); // trigger an event  webView.setNetworkAvailable(false); // reset the webView to its default state 
  This had apparently solved the issues in our S3 Neo android 4.3 device though more testing are needed.
label: no

text: This we hope would result in overall simplification of code in this area and better stability and endurance to mishaps.
label: no

text: textShadowAlpha should have a common global value, should only apply to ActionBar and Button.
label: no

text: textShadowAlpha (rev 18656) is specified in 2 style rules: "ActionBar #titleDisplay" and global.
label: no

text: We should have 1 common global style to allow for easier styling.
label: no

text: The current XD spec calls for .45 in ActionBar and .55 in Button.
label: no

text: Also, a side effect of RadioButton and CheckBox sharing the same base skin as Button is that they support textShadowColor and textShadowAlpha.
label: no

text: Text shadows were in neither of these specs.
label: no

text: I argue that since the text for these skins does not rest on top of a chromeColor, we shouldn't support text shadows for these 2 components.

text: Add an extra parameter to getDependenciesOrder() to filter what kinds of dependencies the caller is interested in (inheritance vs reference).
label: no

text: There is a circular reference (not inheritance) dependency between playerfds.swc and fds.swc, so getDependencyOrder() throws an OEMCircularDependencyException.
label: no

text: Third-party swcs could have the same situation.
label: no

text: For RSL loading order, FB is only interested in inheritance dependencies, but without any way for FB to specify that, getDependenciesOrder() treats all dependencies the same and throws the exception.
label: no

text: Therefore, we should add an extra parameter to getDependenciesOrder() to filter what kinds of dependencies the caller is interested in (inheritance vs reference).

text: Provide a way of dynamically changing the threshold between touch scrolling and selection.
label: no

text: When your finger interacts with a touch screen there is almost always some movement between the mouseDown/mouseMove(s)/mouseUp.
label: no

text: Flex watches these differences to determine if the touch looks like clicking/selecting something or if it looks more like a drag/throw to induce scrolling.
label: no

text: Currently this "slop" threshold is a constant size (20 pixels on a 240dpi device) meaning that if you try to make a small scrolling gesture that went less than 20 pixels it won't be considered a scrolling movement.
label: no

text: This threshold could be made much smaller if the area the finger is touching isn't over something clickable/selectable, for example panning in a Photo viewer application.
label: no

text: It would be great if Flex could detect this kind of a situation and automatically adjust the slop accordingly.
label: no

text: If you compare the Angry Birds and "Settings" apps on Android you will see that panning in the Angry Birds game has a very small slop and the Settings app has a larger slop.
label: no

text: This automatic adjusting should give Flex developers this behavior by default without any changes in their code.
label: no

text: In addition to automatically choosing the slop threshold it might be worthwhile considering providing an API for it too.
label: no

text: For example, if you compare the Angry Birds application on iPad with panning around a photo in the Photos application you will see two different slop thresholds even though neither situation has a risk of selection.
label: no

text: SkinnableContainer: measuredMinWidth/measuredMinHeight contract is broken.
label: no

text: See the attached example: Upon creation the container's measuredMinHeight/minHeight is 0.
label: no

text: This is due to a hack in SkinnableContainerSkin where the contentGroup has its minWidth/minHeight set to 0.
label: no

text: This makes measuredMinWidth/measuredMinHeight obsolete in the whole application seeing as SkinnableContainers are widely used.
label: no

text: One particular use case I have in mind is a modular application where a number of modules are launched in popups.
label: no

text: With this hack in, I can't offer to provide resizing facilities till the natural (measured) minWidth/minHeight of the popup'ed component is reached (The expected behavior).
label: no

text: Instead, I have to tell module developers to set an explicit minWidth/minHeight at the top level view of their module which is annoying for a number of reasons (One of which is that they have to remember to re-evaluate these values everytime they change the content of their module).
label: no

text: I understand the hack was put in place to fix another bug, but it came with its issues too.
label: no

text: Was it worth it ?
label: no

text: Isn't there a better fix ?
label: no

text: API: Since Label, Text, TextInput, and TextArea have a condenseWhite property, RichTextEditor should also.
label: no

text: This bug was imported from another system and requires review from a project committer before some of the details can be marked public.
label: no

text: For more information about historical bugs, please read: You can request a review of this bug report by sending an e-mail to: Please be sure to include the bug number in your request.

label: no

text: And here, we lose the data.
label: no

text: Compaction can break the region/row level atomic when scan even if we pass mvcc to client.
label: no

text: We know that major compaction will actually delete the cells which are deleted by a delete marker.
label: no

text: In order to give a consistent view for a scan, we need to use a map to track the read points for all scanners for a region, and the smallest one will be used for a compaction.
label: no

text: For all delete markers whose mvcc is greater than this value, we will not use it to delete other cells.
label: no

text: And the problem for a scan restart after region move is that, the new RS does not have the information of the scanners opened at the old RS before the client sends scan requests to the new RS which means the read points map is incomplete and the smallest read point maybe greater than the correct value.
label: no

text: So if a major compaction happens at that time, it may delete some cells which should be kept.
label: no

text: However, in our product environment we ever observed the case that both processCallTime and queueCallTime didn't reach the 10s threshold but totalCallTime did, but have no idea what the call is against.

text: enable_table_replication can not perform cyclic replication of a table.
label: no

text: The enable_table_replication operation is broken for cyclic replication of HBase table as we compare all the properties of column families (including REPLICATION_SCOPE).
label: no

text: Below is exactly what happens: 1.
label: no

text: Running "enable_table_replication 'table1' " opeartion on first cluster will set the REPLICATION_SCOPE of all column families to peer id '1'.
label: no

text: This will also create a table on second cluster where REPLICATION_SCOPE is still set to peer id '0'.
label: no

text: Now when we run "enable_table_replication 'table1'" on second cluster, we compare all the properties of table (including REPLICATION_SCOPE_, which obviously is different now.
label: no

text: I am proposing a fix for this issue where we should avoid comparing REPLICATION_SCOPE inside HColumnDescriotor::compareTo() method, especially when replication is not already enabled on the desired table.
label: no

text: I have made that change and it is working.
label: no

text: I will submit the patch soon.
label: no

text: Right now, the API documentation for Table#get(List) and Table#batch(List, Result[]) both leave open the possibility for the ordering of the result array to be independent of the input actions.
label: no

text: In at least the batch method case, ordering of the result array is important in order to know which partial requests failed in the event of an exception.

text: Move MissingSwitchDefault check from checkstyle to error-prone.
label: no

text: Both checkstyle and error-prone can alert when a switch statement is missing a default.
label: no

text: In fact, checkstyle explicitly mentions in their docs that even if you cover all enum cases now, you should still have a default label because the enum could change in the future.
label: no

text: Which seems silly to me, because your analysis tools should still be running in the future and would catch it then.
label: no

text: Se we should migrate the check from checkstyle to a slightly smarter error-prone check.
label: no

text: Unsafe access cleanup.
label: no

text: We have two means of getting at unsafe; UnsafeAccess and then internal to the Bytes class.
label: no

text: They are effectively doing the same thing.
label: no

text: We should have one avenue to Unsafe only.
label: no

text: Many of our paths to Unsafe via UnsafeAccess traverse flags to check if access is available, if it is aligned and the order in which words are written on the machine.
label: no

text: The unsafe access inside Bytes checks on startup what the machine is capable off and then does a static assign of the appropriate class-to-use from there on out.
label: no

text: UnsafeAccess does not do this running the checks everytime.
label: no

text: Would be good to have the Bytes behavior pervasive.
label: no

text: The benefit of one access to Unsafe only is plain.
label: no

text: The benefits we gain removing checks will be harder to measure though should be plain when you disassemble a hot-path; in a (very) rare case, the saved byte codes could be the difference between inlining or not.
label: no

text: Make sure the batches within one region are shipped to the sink clusters in order (branch-1).
label: no

text:
Problem Statement: 
  In the cross-cluster replication validation, we found some cells in source and sink cluster can have the same row key, the same timestamp but different values.
label: no

text: The happens when mutations with the same row key are submitted in batch without specifying the timestamp, and the same timestamp in the unit of millisecond is assigned at the time when they are committed to the WAL.
label: no

text: When this happens, if the major compaction hasn??? happened yet and you scan the table, you can find some cells have the same row key, the same timestamps but different values, like the first three rows in the following table.
label: no

text:
Row Key 1 CF0::Column 1 Timestatmp 1 Value 1
Row Key 1 CF0::Column 1 Timestatmp 1 Value 2
Row Key 1 CF0::Column 1 Timestatmp 1 Value 3
Row Key 2 CF0::Column 1 Timestatmp 2 Value 4
Row Key 3 CF0::Column 1 Timestatmp 4 Value 5
The ordering of the first three rows is indeterminate in the presence of the cross-replication, so after compaction, in the master cluster you will see ???ow Key 1, CF0::Column1, Timestamp1??? having the value 3, but in the slave cluster, you might see the cell having one of the three possible values 1, 2, 3, which results in data inconsistency issue between the master and slave clusters.
label: no

text:
Root Cause Analysis: 
  In HBaseInterClusterReplicationEndpoint.createBatches() of branch-1.3, the WAL entries from the same region could be split into different batches according to replication RPC limit and these batches are shipped by ReplicationSource concurrently, so the batches for the same region could arrive at the sink in the slave clusters then apply to the region synchronously in indeterminate order.
label: no
no

text: append() and increment() may result in inconsistent result on retries.
label: no

text:
append() and increment() api can give inconsistent result in following scenarios : 
  1- For eg, if the client does not receive the response in the specified time, it retries.
label: no

text: Now the first call to increment/append is already done and this retry will again make the operation to succeed.
label: no

text: 2- Now if the sync() to WAL fails we get an IOException, on getting an exception there is a retry done which again results in the doing the increment/append again.
label: no

text: When may need some sort of roll back for the second problem.
label: no

text: For the first one we need to see how to handle this.
label: no

text: With HFile v2, the region server will always perform an extra copy of source files.
label: no

text: With HFile v2 implementation in HBase 0.94 & 0.96, the region server will use HFileSystem as its <font color="blue">fs</font>.
label: no

text: When it performs bulk load in Store.bulkLoadHFile(), it checks if its <font color="blue">fs</font> is the same as <font color="blue">srcFs</font>, which however will be DistributedFileSystem.
label: no

text: Consequently, it will always perform an extra copy of source files.
label: no

text: Enable server side limit default on the size of results returned (to prevent OOMs).
label: no

text: This should be easily avoidable, if the client can use a Scan instead of a Get, and/or use batching to reduce the size.
label: no

text: But, it seems difficult to enforce this.
label: no

text: Moreover, once in a while, there may be genuine outliers/bad clients, that cause such large requests.
label: no

text: We need to handle such situations gracefully, and not have the RS reboot for things that can be prevented.
label: no

text: The proposal here is to enforce a maximum response size at the Server end, so we are not at the mercy of the client's good behavior to let the server running.
label: no

text: We already log large responses.
label: no

text: But, if the response is too large, it just kills the server.
label: no

text: We don't have it logged, and the only way to find out is to go through the heap dump.
label: no

text: More importantly, our availability/reliability numbers will go down because the whole region/regionserver fails instead of just the single bad request.
label: no

text: I think it will be useful for the server to maintain a maximum request size that it will serve.
label: no

text: Something large like 2-3G, so normal operations do not need to be bothered.
label: no

text: If a single get/scan operation exceeds the size, we will just throw an exception for the request.
label: no

text: Globally Barriered Procedure mechanism.
label: no

text:
This is a simplified version of what was proposed in 
   <URL>.
label: no

text: Instead of claiming to be a 2pc or 3pc implementation (which implies logging at each actor, and recovery operations) this is just provides a best effort global barrier mechanism called a Procedure.
label: no

text: Users need only to implement a methods to acquireBarrier, to act when insideBarrier, and to releaseBarrier that use the ExternalException cooperative error checking mechanism.
label: no

text: Globally consistent snapshots require the ability to quiesce writes to a set of region servers before a the snapshot operation is executed.
label: no

text: Also if any node fails, it needs to be able to notify them so that they abort.
label: no

text: The first cut of other online snapshots don't need the fully barrier but may still use this for its error propagation mechanisms.
label: no

text: This version removes the extra layer incurred in the previous implementation due to the use of generics, separates the coordinator and members, and reduces the amount of inheritance used in favor of composition.

text: "hbck -fixReferenceFiles" checks for write permissions in / even if sidelineDir is specified.
label: no

text: We found a situation where a temporary reference file got left in META's recovered.edits directory and this was causing hbck to report inconsistency with HBase.
label: no

text: When trying to repair it with the "hbck -fixReferenceFiles" command, an access control exception was thrown, because hbck was trying to put the sidelined reference file in the root of HDFS and the hbase user did not have permissions.
label: no

text:
But even after specifying a "sidelineDir" (hbck -fixReferenceFiles -sidelineDir hdfs://<namespace>/tmp), the same exception was thrown (logs obfuscated below): 
  INFO util.HBaseFsck: Trying to sildeline reference filehdfs://<namespace>/hbase/.
label: no

text: META.
label: no

text: /1028685194/recovered.
label: no

text: temp to hdfs://<namespace>/0000000000000000016.
label: no

text:
temp  Exception in thread "main" org.apache.hadoop.security.AccessControlException: Permission denied: user=hbase, access=WRITE, inode="/":hdfs:hadoop:drwxr-xr-x  
  Since the operation requires moving data around in HDFS, we tried the same command as the "hdfs" user which should have no permission problems, but an exception was thrown nonetheless: 
  ...  WARN util.HBaseFsck: Got AccessControlException when preCheckPermission  org.apache.hadoop.security.AccessControlException: Permission denied: action=WRITE path=hdfs://<namespace>/hbase/<del>ROOT</del> user=hdfs  
  Ultimately in order to get this working, we ran this command to tell hbck to not run it's prechecks: 
  hbase hbck -fixReferenceFiles -sidelineDir hdfs://<namespace>/tmp -ignorePreCheckPermission 
  A few thoughts here: 
  1) it seems that / is a bad default location to attempt to sideline files 
  2) shouldn't hbck be run as the hbase user?
label: no

text: If so, it should sideline files to a directory it has write permissions to.
label: no

text: 3) if we expect hbck to be run as the hdfs user, permissions should not be denied that user when HDFS itself will not deny them.

text: For a composite row key, Phoenix strips off trailing null columns values in the row key.
label: no

text: The reason this is important is that then new nullable row key columns can be added to a schema without requiring any data upgrade to existing rows.
label: no

text: Otherwise, adding new row key columns to the end of a schema becomes extremely cumbersome, as you'd need to delete all existing rows and add them back with a row key that includes a null value.
label: no

text: Otherwise, if Phoenix has to specialize this, we'd lose the interop piece which is the justification for switching our type system to this new one in the first place.

text: clean clearBufferOnFail behavior and deprecate it.
label: no

text: The behavior with clearBufferOnFail is very fishy.
label: no

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  So by default, a HTable has 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   autoflush == true 
   clearBufferOnFail == true 
   
  BUT, if you call setAutoFlush(false), you have 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   autoflush == false 
   clearBufferOnFail == false 
   
  So: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   you're setting two parameters instead of only one, without being told so.
label: no

text:
a side effect is that failed operations will be tried twice: 
   one in the standard process 
   one in the table close, as we're flushing the buffer again 
   
  I would like to: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   deprecate clearBufferOnFail.
label: no

text: FixedDateFormat improvements.
label: no

text:
Proposed changes: 
   
   improve thread-safety of <tt>FixedDateFormat::updateMidnightMillis 
   expose <tt>FixedDateFormat::millisSinceMidnight as a public method 
   
  In multi-threaded scenarios where time does not move forward monotonically, the implementation of <tt>FixedDateFormat::updateMidnightMillis can result in corrupted time stamps.
label: no

text: In a project I am involved in we have a custom PatternConverter that uses FixedDateFormat to format the "event time".
label: no

text: In these (artificial) tests, event time does not always move forward, so the <tt>updateMidnightMillis is called concurrently with varying values.
label: no

text: Making <tt>FixedDateFormat::millisSinceMidnight public would provide a performant and convenient way to strip off the date component.
label: no

text: Add support for appending common suffix to each line of throwable stack trace.
label: no

text: The suffix can be configured by patterns just like patterns used elsewhere.
label: no

text: For example, pattern <tt>%xEx{suffix(- %mdc{key})} will append a string generated by pattern <tt>-  and <tt>%mdc{key}.
label: no

text: But patterns that handles throwable will be automatically ignored, because they will make the rendered result confusing.
label: no

text: So pattern <tt>%xEx{suffix(- %rEx%mdc{key})} has the same effect with <tt>%xEx{suffix(- %mdc{key})}, as if the nested <tt>%rEx pattern has never appeared.

text: Memory leaking of replacement parameters in case of enableThreadlocals=true.
label: no

text: Use case: 1) I have a thread pool with quite large number of threads (around 100) 2) Threads from the pool sometimes process some heavy objects.
label: no

text: Threads are not actively writing into logs (so, a thread may process a task and does not log any message).
label: no

text: 3) As a part of processing for some objects in some non-frequently used branch a thread logged a message with heavy replacement parameters (parameterized log message is used).
label: no

text: In this case such heavy replacement parameters are not garbage collected until another message will not written within the same thread because thread-local ReusableParameterizedMessage and MutableLogEvent objects keep references to the replacement parameters.

    <URL> returns returns 400 as expected since, wrong range query is fired 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  but for this request, <tt>
    <URL> returns 500(Internal server error) instead of 400(Bad Request) 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  This is because in case of <tt>DateField any parse exception is wrapped in <tt>SolrException with code set to 400

text: Consistence problem when in-sync replicas are DOWN.
label: no

text: Currently, we will meet consistency problem when in-sync replicas are DOWN.
label: no

text: For example: 1.
label: no

text: A collection with 1 shard with 1 leader and 2 replicas 2.
label: no

text: Nodes contain 2 replicas go down 3.
label: no

text: The leader receives an update A, success 4.
label: no

text: The node contains the leader goes down 5.
label: no

text: 2 replicas come back 6.
label: no

text:
One of them become leader --> But they shouldn't become leader since they missed the update A 
  A solution to this issue : 
   
   The idea here is using term value of each replica (
    <URL>) will be enough to tell that a replica received the latest updates or not.
label: no

text: Therefore only replicas with the highest term can become the leader.
label: no

text:
There are a couple of things need to be done on this issue 
     
     When leader receives the first updates, its term should be changed from 0 -> 1, so further replicas added to the same shard won't be able to become leader (their term = 0) until they finish recovery 
     For DOWN replicas, the leader should also need to check (in DUP.finish()) that those replicas have term less than leader before return results to users 
     Just by looking at term value of replica, it is not enough to tell us that replica is in-sync with leader or not.
label: no

text: Because that replica might not finish the recovery process.
label: no

text: We need to introduce another flag (stored on shard term node on ZK) to tell us that replica finished recovery or not.
label: no

     <URL> This JIRA issue is closed because it won't be committed in its current form.

text: There currently isn't a solution in Solr for doing geospatial filtering on documents that have a variable number of points.
label: no

text: This scenario occurs when there is location extraction (i.e. via a "gazateer") occurring on free text.
label: no

text: None, one, or many geospatial locations might be extracted from any given document and users want to limit their search results to those occurring in a user-specified area.
label: no

text: I've implemented this by furthering the GeoHash based work in Lucene/Solr with a geohash prefix based filter.
label: no

text: A geohash refers to a lat-lon box on the earth.
label: no

text: Each successive character added further subdivides the box into a 4x8 (or 8x4 depending on the even/odd length of the geohash) grid.
label: no

text: The first step in this scheme is figuring out which geohash grid squares cover the user's search query.
label: no

text: I've added various extra methods to GeoHashUtils (and added tests) to assist in this purpose.
label: no

text: Once a matching geohash grid is found, the points therein are compared against the user's query to see if it matches.
label: no

text: I created an abstraction GeoShape extended by subclasses named PointDistance... and CartesianBox....
label: no

text: to support different queried shapes so that the filter need not care about these details.
label: no

text: This work was presented at LuceneRevolution in Boston on October 8th.

text: Doc Filters for Auto-suggest, spell checking, terms component, etc..
label: no

text: It is often useful to be able to restrict down the results of auto suggest, spell checking, term components to only show results that are in documents that are in a filter.
label: no

text: For instance, in multitenant solutions, it is common to mix content from multiple clients into the same index and then use filters to restrict the search space.
label: no

text: This, however, does not happen for things like auto-suggest, spell checking etc. so it often happens that one gets suggestions for terms that are not in the filtered set.
label: no

text: If we could use a filter when giving suggestions, spellings, etc. we could then only show values that the user is guaranteed to be able to see.

text:

text:
This issue is discussed in

text: Zookeeper session expiry during shard leader election can cause multiple leaders.
label: no

text: However the threads that were processing the election are still present (and could believe the host won the election).
label: no

text: They will then incorrectly create leader nodes once a new ZooKeeper session is established.
label: no

text: This introduces a subtle race condition that could cause two hosts to become leader.
label: no

text:
Scenario: 
  a three machine cluster, all of the machines are restarting at approximately the same time.
label: no

text: The first machine starts, writes a leader_elect ephemeral node, it's the only candidate in the election so it wins and starts the leadership process.
label: no

text: A new ZK session is established, and ElectionContext.cancelElection is called.
label: no

text: Then register() is called and a new set of leader_elect ephemeral nodes are created.
label: no

text: During the period between the ZK session expiring, and new set of leader_elect nodes being created the second machine starts.
label: no

text: It creates its leader_elect ephemeral nodes, as there are no other nodes it wins the election and starts the leadership process.
label: no

text: There is now a race between machine1 & machine2, both of whom think they are the leader.
label: no

text: So far, this isn't too bad, because the machine that loses the race will fail when it tries to create the /collection/name/leader/shard1 node (as it already exists), and will rejoin the election.
label: no

text: While this is happening, machine3 has started and has queued for leadership behind machine2.
label: no

text: If the loser of the race is machine2, when it rejoins the election it cancels the current context, deleting it's leader_elect ephemeral nodes.
label: no

text: At this point, machine3 believes it has become leader (the watcher it has on the leader_elect node fires), and it runs the LeaderElector::checkIfIAmLeader method.
label: no

text: So, machine1 won the race with machine2 and declared its leadership and created the nodes.
label: no

text: However, machine3 has just deleted them, and recreated them for itself.
label: no

text: So machine1 and machine3 both believe they are the leader.
label: no

text: That election context logic already has checks on the closed flag, so they should exit if they see it has been closed.
label: no

text: I'm working on a patch for this.
label: no

text: factor out a SearchGroupsFieldCommandResult class.
label: no

text: The (new) <tt>SearchGroupsFieldCommandResult class for the (existing) <tt>SearchGroupsFieldCommand command to be similar to the existing <tt>QueryCommandResult class for the <tt>QueryCommand command.
label: no

text: Change the default of facet.distrib.mco from false to true.
label: no

text: <URL> added a new query option facet.distrib.mco which when set to true would allow the use of facet.mincount=1 in cloud mode.
label: no

text: The previous behavior, and current default, is that facet.mincount=0 when in cloud mode.
label: no

text: What exactly would be changed?
label: no

text: The default of facet.distrib.mco=false would be changed to facet.distrib.mco=true.
label: no

text: When is this option effective?
label: no

text:
From the documentation,

What is the result of turning this option on?
label: no

text: When facet.distrib.mco=true is used, and the conditions above are met, then when Solr is sending requests off to the various shards it will include facet.mincount=1.
label: no

text: The result of this is that only terms with a count > 0 will be considered when processing the request for that shard.
label: no

text:
From the comments in 
   <URL>,  
  <blockquote> 
   Consider you asked for up to 10 terms from shardA with mincount=1 but you received only 5 terms back.
label: no

text: In this case you know, definitively, that a term seen in the response from shardB but not in the response from shardA could have at most a count of 0 in shardA.
label: no

text: If it had any other count in shardA then it would have been returned in the response from shardA.
label: no

text: Also, if you asked for up to 10 terms from shardA with mincount=1 and you get back a response with 10 terms having a count >= 1 then the response is identical to the one you'd have received if mincount=0.
label: no

text: Because of this, there isn't a scenario where the response would result in more work than would have been required if mincount=0.
label: no

text: For this reason, the decrease in required work when mincount=1 is always either a moot point or a net win.
label: no

text: The belief here is that it is safe to change the default of facet.distrib.mco such that facet.mincount=1 will be used when appropriate.
label: no

text: Derive from Edge configs.
label: no

text: I am working on making Apache Flink run on top of Tez.
label: no

text: Flink uses its own serialization and deserialization machinery and does not rely on Hadoop Writables.
label: no

text: To pass data between Tez processors, we encapsulate objects that are (de)serialized by Flink inside a Hadoop writable, and use that writable as the value in the Tez key-value pairs that are being read and written by operators.
label: no

text: This requires a Flink type serializer object to be present at the Tez reader and the input classes.
label: no

text:
To do that, we had to create a custom input reader and a custom input that derive from KeyValueReader and AbstractLogical input respectively: 
  
   <URL> 
  
   <URL> 
  This also meant creating custom edge configs to return the correct input type (in this case FlinkUnorderedKVInput): 
  
   <URL> 
  
   <URL> 
  To create these, we needed to derive from UnorderedKVEdgeConfig and UnorderedPartitionedKVEdgeConfig respectively, and change some fields from private to protected (a patch showing the changes is attached).
label: no

text: We are not using the sorting facilities of Tez, we rather use the Flink sort operators inside Tez processors.
label: no

text: This is the reason that the Ordered classes are not modified.
label: no

text: I was wondering if there might be a better way to do this, and if not, whether the change described in the patch would be acceptable for the next Tez release.

  For each node: 
   
   pass a client timestamp in the snapshot call corresponding to "now" 
   snapshot the tables using the existing procedure 
   walk backwards through the linked snapshot sstables in that snapshot 
   if the earliest update in that sstable is after the client's timestamp, delete the sstable in the snapshot 
   if the earliest update in the sstable is before the client's timestamp, then look at the last update.

text: Reduce catalog's memory footprint.

text:
Currently, for a table with 2 int columns and 1 int partition column and without incremental stats, we use: 
   
   ~930B per partition out of which ~500B are used on hmsParameters_ (<String, String>Map), ~190B on cachedMsPartitionDescriptor_, and ~200B (depending on path) on location.

text: ~800B per file descriptor out of which ~530B go to file_blocks and the rest are used for storing the file_name.

text: A table like that with 100,000 partitions and 10 files per partition requires 1GB and 1.4GB of memory w and w/o incremental stats, respectively.

text: Catalog loading threads can be wasted waiting for a large table to load.
label: yes

text: When there are multiple requests to the catalogd to prioritize loading the same table, then several catalog loading threads may end up waiting for that single table to be loaded, effectively reducing the number of catalog loading threads.
label: yes

text: After issuing a load request, an impalad will wait 2m for the metadata to arrive, and then send the request again every 2m.
label: yes

text: So if a large table takes 20m to load, then a single query could issue 10 table-loading requests which ultimately hog 10 table-loading threads in the catalogd.
label: yes

text: However, the code does not prevent multiple threads from entering Catalog.getTableOrLoad() which will block on the same future for the same table.
label: yes

text: Reproduction: The issue is easy to reproduce by simulating a long table load and doing several concurrent loads of the same table from an impalad.

text: rethink stress test binary search cutoff point.
label: yes

text:
While working on 
   <URL> I see that during a binary search, a lot of queries that are meant to be tested with spilling are not set at any different mem_limit than they were for their non-spillable counterparts.
label: yes

text: This is due to both the default data scales of the stress test (TPCH 100, TPCDS 300) and the fact that <tt>MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB = 50 in <tt>concurrent_select.py.
label: yes

text: For queries that only use roughly 200 MB, a 50MB threshold is a rather large percentage.
label: yes

text: This means the binary search is "giving up" sooner than it could.
label: yes

text:
There are some options: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   drop MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB completely and only rely on MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_PC, which is 0.975.
label: yes

text: For a 200 MB query, this would effectively be a threshold of 5MB.
label: yes

text: This would lead to a more precise binary search, but one that would take longer to complete.
label: yes

text: keep MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB but only put it in play for either larger queries or larger data sets.
label: yes

text: If the column ranges are large (i.e. multiple I/O buffers) or we're reading from SSDs where random access is fairly efficient, this may not matter very much.
label: yes

text: If we are reading each column into a single smaller I/O buffer but multiple columns would fit in a larger I/O buffer, we would probably be better off doing a single I/O for that column.
label: yes

text: Sorting the scan ranges by file offset would improve the odds of being able to read each subsequent column without an additional seek and will also improve locality for the disk's internal cache.
label: yes

text: Based on some superficial googling, a lot of drives have 64M or 128M internal caches, which is large enough that it could be useful but small enough that, if we do I/O from a 256MB+ Parquet file in a completely random order, we're reducing the chances of getting cache hits significantly.
label: yes

text: may help a lot here, since it will tell us upfront what the memory budget is for I/O.

text: While debugging performance issues in a Spark program, I've found a simple way to slow down Spark 1.6 significantly by filling the RDD memory cache.
label: yes

text: This seems to be a regression, because setting "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" fixes the problem.
label: yes

text:
Here is a repro that is just a simple program that fills the memory cache of Spark using a MEMORY_ONLY cached RDD (but of course this comes up in more complex situations, too): 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  If I call it the following way, it completes in around 5 minutes on my Laptop, while often stopping for slow Full GC cycles.
label: yes

text: I can also see with jvisualvm (Visual GC plugin) that the old generation of JVM is 96.8% filled.
label: yes

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  If I add any one of the below flags, then the run-time drops to around 40-50 seconds and the difference is coming from the drop in GC times: --conf "spark.memory.fraction=0.6" OR --conf "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" OR --driver-java-options "-XX:NewRatio=3" 
  All the other cache types except for DISK_ONLY produce similar symptoms.
label: yes

text: It looks like that the problem is that the amount of data Spark wants to store long-term ends up being larger than the old generation size in the JVM and this triggers Full GC repeatedly.
label: yes

text:
I did some research: 
   
   In Spark 1.6, spark.memory.fraction is the upper limit on cache size.
label: yes

text: In Spark 1.5, spark.storage.memoryFraction is the upper limit in cache size.
label: yes

text:
It defaults to 0.6 and... 
   
    <URL> even says that it shouldn't be bigger than the size of the old generation.
label: yes

text: On the other hand, OpenJDK's default NewRatio is 2, which means an old generation size of 66%.
label: yes

text:
This is not a surprise: 
   <URL> explains that storageFraction is not an upper-limit but a lower limit-like thing on the size of Spark's cache.
label: yes

text: The real upper limit is spark.memory.fraction.
label: yes

text: Is it a goal for Spark to support heavy caching with default parameters and without GC breakdown?

text:
For instance:

Start with a new repository and create the following hierarchy:

a -- b -- d
  |
  +- c


Create a dump filtered to include only the a/b hierarchy:

$ svnadmin dump repos | svndumpfilter include a/b >dump.txt"


Import the filtered dump into a newly created repository:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ...svn: File not found: transaction '1', path 'a/b'
$


A workaround should be to create the a directory before importing:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ... done.

text: We believe that the most sensible solution to this is that the rollback should respond to the same timeout as the connection.

text: Rather than just blocking when RAM is full we could have a high-water mark where we start spooling messages to disk if there is not sufficient RAM to hold the messages.
label: yes

text: The good thing about this approch is that it avoids blocking the producers when RAM is full; the downside is that once spooling starts, the producer will be slowed down to the speed of the disk spooling (as due to RAM exhaustion under steady state, the producer will have to wait for the message to be spooled to disk so that it can evict it from RAM so that it can send the next message).
label: yes

text: Though the journal is quite fast so the slow down shouldn't be too many orders of magnitude (and is better than making things appear to 'lock up' while we wait for the slowest consumer to acknowledge more messages).
label: yes

text: We typically use the current thread in the broker to dispatch to all the available non-durable consumers for performance - as this hugely reduces the context switching and increases performance.
label: yes

text:
However (see 
   <URL>) sometimes this can cause one dead consumer to block a producer.
label: yes

What I think should happen is something along the lines of the following: 
  For each node: 
   
   pass a client timestamp in the snapshot call corresponding to "now" 
   snapshot the tables using the existing procedure 
   walk backwards through the linked snapshot sstables in that snapshot 
   if the earliest update in that sstable is after the client's timestamp, delete the sstable in the snapshot 
   if the earliest update in the sstable is before the client's timestamp, then look at the last update.

   <URL> I see that during a binary search, a lot of queries that are meant to be tested with spilling are not set at any different mem_limit than they were for their non-spillable counterparts.

text: This is due to both the default data scales of the stress test (TPCH 100, TPCDS 300) and the fact that <tt>MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB = 50 in <tt>concurrent_select.py.

text: For queries that only use roughly 200 MB, a 50MB threshold is a rather large percentage.
label: yes

text: This means the binary search is "giving up" sooner than it could.
label: yes

text:
There are some options: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   drop MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB completely and only rely on MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_PC, which is 0.975.

text: For a 200 MB query, this would effectively be a threshold of 5MB.

text: This would lead to a more precise binary search, but one that would take longer to complete.

text:

  <SOURCECODE> 
  If I call it the following way, it completes in around 5 minutes on my Laptop, while often stopping for slow Full GC cycles.

text: I can also see with jvisualvm (Visual GC plugin) that the old generation of JVM is 96.8% filled.

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  If I add any one of the below flags, then the run-time drops to around 40-50 seconds and the difference is coming from the drop in GC times: --conf "spark.memory.fraction=0.6" OR --conf "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" OR --driver-java-options "-XX:NewRatio=3" 
  All the other cache types except for DISK_ONLY produce similar symptoms.

text: It looks like that the problem is that the amount of data Spark wants to store long-term ends up being larger than the old generation size in the JVM and this triggers Full GC repeatedly.

text:
For instance:

Start with a new repository and create the following hierarchy:

a -- b -- d
  |
  +- c


Create a dump filtered to include only the a/b hierarchy:

$ svnadmin dump repos | svndumpfilter include a/b >dump.txt"


Import the filtered dump into a newly created repository:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ...svn: File not found: transaction '1', path 'a/b'
$


A workaround should be to create the a directory before importing:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ... done.
label: yes

text:
The lazy open bit is good (and greatly
reduces the number of file handles held open during a repository diff via
ra-serf), but we need to ensure that those stream do, in fact, get eventually
opened.
label: yes

text:
To accomplish this, two things need to occur:

-  The error codes in svn_error_codes.h need to be fragmented by their general
module, to create separate "spaces" for those codes with room for addition of
new codes in each module "space".
label: yes

text:
It would be really nice if I could arrange things so (of course the
details are to
be scripted, the subversion role is to provide needed hooks their
parameters):
- if the Windows developer commits, the file is transcoded from
win-1250 to iso-8859-2
   so the repository contains the files in iso-8859-2 encoding
- if the Windows developer updates/checks out/diffs/???
label: yes

text:
Some additional related thoughts:
- subversion handles content-type property, maybe it would be worthful
   to keep the character set too (after-all Polish HTML pages
   has usually 
      Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-2
   instead of usual text/html, same apply for text/plain), I would imagine
   keeping content-charset property and (in case it exits) using it
   while producing Content-Type in HTTP header
- to implement transcoding I described, one would need some 'sandbox
property'
   (in this case 'sandbox charset' - win-1250 for Windows and
iso-8859-2 otherwise)
- maybe in some future we could keep the data in UTF-8 and use simple
   encodings only in sandboxes?
label: yes

text: Rather than just blocking when RAM is full we could have a high-water mark where we start spooling messages to disk if there is not sufficient RAM to hold the messages.
label: yes

text: The good thing about this approch is that it avoids blocking the producers when RAM is full; the downside is that once spooling starts, the producer will be slowed down to the speed of the disk spooling (as due to RAM exhaustion under steady state, the producer will have to wait for the message to be spooled to disk so that it can evict it from RAM so that it can send the next message).
label: yes

text: Though the journal is quite fast so the slow down shouldn't be too many orders of magnitude (and is better than making things appear to 'lock up' while we wait for the slowest consumer to acknowledge more messages).
label: yes

text: We typically use the current thread in the broker to dispatch to all the available non-durable consumers for performance - as this hugely reduces the context switching and increases performance.
label: yes

text:
However (see 
   <URL>) sometimes this can cause one dead consumer to block a producer.
label: yes

text: Some folks may want to switch this strategy to use slower asynchronous dispatch with a thread pool to reduce the risk of blocking a producer at the expensive of lower performance
label: yes

text: While debugging performance issues in a Spark program, I've found a simple way to slow down Spark 1.6 significantly by filling the RDD memory cache.
label: yes

text: This seems to be a regression, because setting "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" fixes the problem.
label: yes

text:
Here is a repro that is just a simple program that fills the memory cache of Spark using a MEMORY_ONLY cached RDD (but of course this comes up in more complex situations, too): 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  If I call it the following way, it completes in around 5 minutes on my Laptop, while often stopping for slow Full GC cycles.
label: yes

text: I can also see with jvisualvm (Visual GC plugin) that the old generation of JVM is 96.8% filled.
label: yes

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  If I add any one of the below flags, then the run-time drops to around 40-50 seconds and the difference is coming from the drop in GC times: --conf "spark.memory.fraction=0.6" OR --conf "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" OR --driver-java-options "-XX:NewRatio=3" 
  All the other cache types except for DISK_ONLY produce similar symptoms.
label: yes

text: It looks like that the problem is that the amount of data Spark wants to store long-term ends up being larger than the old generation size in the JVM and this triggers Full GC repeatedly.
label: yes

text:
I did some research: 
   
   In Spark 1.6, spark.memory.fraction is the upper limit on cache size.
label: yes

text: In Spark 1.5, spark.storage.memoryFraction is the upper limit in cache size.
label: yes

text:
It defaults to 0.6 and... 
   
    <URL> even says that it shouldn't be bigger than the size of the old generation.
label: yes

text: On the other hand, OpenJDK's default NewRatio is 2, which means an old generation size of 66%.
label: yes

text:
This is not a surprise: 
   <URL> explains that storageFraction is not an upper-limit but a lower limit-like thing on the size of Spark's cache.
label: yes

text: The real upper limit is spark.memory.fraction.
label: yes

text: Is it a goal for Spark to support heavy caching with default parameters and without GC breakdown?
label: yes

text:
For instance:

Start with a new repository and create the following hierarchy:

a -- b -- d
  |
  +- c


Create a dump filtered to include only the a/b hierarchy:

$ svnadmin dump repos | svndumpfilter include a/b >dump.txt"


Import the filtered dump into a newly created repository:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ...svn: File not found: transaction '1', path 'a/b'
$


A workaround should be to create the a directory before importing:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ... done.

- subversion handles content-type property, maybe it would be worthful
   to keep the character set too (after-all Polish HTML pages

   instead of usual text/html, same apply for text/plain), I would imagine
   keeping content-charset property and (in case it exits) using it
   while producing Content-Type in HTTP header
- to implement transcoding I described, one would need some 'sandbox
property'
   (in this case 'sandbox charset' - win-1250 for Windows and

- maybe in some future we could keep the data in UTF-8 and use simple
   encodings only in sandboxes?

text: Rather than just blocking when RAM is full we could have a high-water mark where we start spooling messages to disk if there is not sufficient RAM to hold the messages.
label: yes

text: The good thing about this approch is that it avoids blocking the producers when RAM is full; the downside is that once spooling starts, the producer will be slowed down to the speed of the disk spooling (as due to RAM exhaustion under steady state, the producer will have to wait for the message to be spooled to disk so that it can evict it from RAM so that it can send the next message).
label: yes

text: Though the journal is quite fast so the slow down shouldn't be too many orders of magnitude (and is better than making things appear to 'lock up' while we wait for the slowest consumer to acknowledge more messages).
label: yes

text: We typically use the current thread in the broker to dispatch to all the available non-durable consumers for performance - as this hugely reduces the context switching and increases performance.
label: yes

text:
However (see 
   <URL>) sometimes this can cause one dead consumer to block a producer.
label: yes

text: Some folks may want to switch this strategy to use slower asynchronous dispatch with a thread pool to reduce the risk of blocking a producer at the expensive of lower performance
label: yes

text: Catalog loading threads can be wasted waiting for a large table to load.
label: yes

text: When there are multiple requests to the catalogd to prioritize loading the same table, then several catalog loading threads may end up waiting for that single table to be loaded, effectively reducing the number of catalog loading threads.

text: After issuing a load request, an impalad will wait 2m for the metadata to arrive, and then send the request again every 2m.
label: yes

text: So if a large table takes 20m to load, then a single query could issue 10 table-loading requests which ultimately hog 10 table-loading threads in the catalogd.

text:
While working on 
   <URL> I see that during a binary search, a lot of queries that are meant to be tested with spilling are not set at any different mem_limit than they were for their non-spillable counterparts.
label: yes

text: This is due to both the default data scales of the stress test (TPCH 100, TPCDS 300) and the fact that <tt>MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB = 50 in <tt>concurrent_select.py.
label: yes

text: For queries that only use roughly 200 MB, a 50MB threshold is a rather large percentage.
label: yes

text: This means the binary search is "giving up" sooner than it could.
label: yes

text:
There are some options: 
  <ul class="alternate" type="square"> 
   drop MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB completely and only rely on MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_PC, which is 0.975.
label: yes

text: For a 200 MB query, this would effectively be a threshold of 5MB.
label: yes

text: This would lead to a more precise binary search, but one that would take longer to complete.
label: yes

text: keep MEM_LIMIT_EQ_THRESHOLD_MB but only put it in play for either larger queries or larger data sets.
label: yes

text: If the column ranges are large (i.e. multiple I/O buffers) or we're reading from SSDs where random access is fairly efficient, this may not matter very much.
label: yes

text: If we are reading each column into a single smaller I/O buffer but multiple columns would fit in a larger I/O buffer, we would probably be better off doing a single I/O for that column.
label: yes

text: Sorting the scan ranges by file offset would improve the odds of being able to read each subsequent column without an additional seek and will also improve locality for the disk's internal cache.
label: yes

text: Based on some superficial googling, a lot of drives have 64M or 128M internal caches, which is large enough that it could be useful but small enough that, if we do I/O from a 256MB+ Parquet file in a completely random order, we're reducing the chances of getting cache hits significantly.

text: may help a lot here, since it will tell us upfront what the memory budget is for I/O.

text: While debugging performance issues in a Spark program, I've found a simple way to slow down Spark 1.6 significantly by filling the RDD memory cache.
label: yes

text: This seems to be a regression, because setting "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" fixes the problem.
label: yes

text:
Here is a repro that is just a simple program that fills the memory cache of Spark using a MEMORY_ONLY cached RDD (but of course this comes up in more complex situations, too): 
  <SOURCECODE> 
  If I call it the following way, it completes in around 5 minutes on my Laptop, while often stopping for slow Full GC cycles.
label: yes

text: I can also see with jvisualvm (Visual GC plugin) that the old generation of JVM is 96.8% filled.
label: yes

text:
<SOURCECODE> 
  If I add any one of the below flags, then the run-time drops to around 40-50 seconds and the difference is coming from the drop in GC times: --conf "spark.memory.fraction=0.6" OR --conf "spark.memory.useLegacyMode=true" OR --driver-java-options "-XX:NewRatio=3" 
  All the other cache types except for DISK_ONLY produce similar symptoms.
label: yes

text: It looks like that the problem is that the amount of data Spark wants to store long-term ends up being larger than the old generation size in the JVM and this triggers Full GC repeatedly.
label: yes

text:
I did some research: 
   
   In Spark 1.6, spark.memory.fraction is the upper limit on cache size.
label: yes

text: In Spark 1.5, spark.storage.memoryFraction is the upper limit in cache size.
label: yes

text:
It defaults to 0.6 and... 
   
    <URL> even says that it shouldn't be bigger than the size of the old generation.
label: yes

text: On the other hand, OpenJDK's default NewRatio is 2, which means an old generation size of 66%.
label: yes

text:
This is not a surprise: 
   <URL> explains that storageFraction is not an upper-limit but a lower limit-like thing on the size of Spark's cache.
label: yes

text: The real upper limit is spark.memory.fraction.

text:
For instance:

Start with a new repository and create the following hierarchy:

a -- b -- d
  |
  +- c


Create a dump filtered to include only the a/b hierarchy:

$ svnadmin dump repos | svndumpfilter include a/b >dump.txt"


Import the filtered dump into a newly created repository:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ...svn: File not found: transaction '1', path 'a/b'
$


A workaround should be to create the a directory before importing:

$ svnadmin load filtered <dump.txt
<<< Started new transaction, based on original revision 1
     * adding path : a/b ... done.

reduces the number of file handles held open during a repository diff via
ra-serf), but we need to ensure that those stream do, in fact, get eventually
opened.
label: yes

text:
To accomplish this, two things need to occur:

-  The error codes in svn_error_codes.h need to be fragmented by their general
module, to create separate "spaces" for those codes with room for addition of
new codes in each module "space".
label: yes

text:
It would be really nice if I could arrange things so (of course the
details are to
be scripted, the subversion role is to provide needed hooks their
parameters):
- if the Windows developer commits, the file is transcoded from
win-1250 to iso-8859-2
   so the repository contains the files in iso-8859-2 encoding
- if the Windows developer updates/checks out/diffs/???
label: yes

text:
Some additional related thoughts:
- subversion handles content-type property, maybe it would be worthful
   to keep the character set too (after-all Polish HTML pages
   has usually 
      Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-2
   instead of usual text/html, same apply for text/plain), I would imagine
   keeping content-charset property and (in case it exits) using it
   while producing Content-Type in HTTP header
- to implement transcoding I described, one would need some 'sandbox
property'
   (in this case 'sandbox charset' - win-1250 for Windows and
iso-8859-2 otherwise)
- maybe in some future we could keep the data in UTF-8 and use simple
   encodings only in sandboxes?
label: yes
